ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to read scientific papers; new developments in genetics research; the importance of keeping up with the latest research
My ability to read scientific papers has been majorly improved. The course also motivated me to keep up with the latest publications and news.
Learning how to thoroughly read and understand genetics papers
How to read difficult scientific papers and interpret figures
Learned a ton about reading research papers
In learned how to read academic papers a lot better. I also learned about various tools/statistics used in this field of research.
How to read, understand, and discuss scientific papers.
How to read scientific papers in a more effective and rewarding way.

I gained a much broader and more complete understanding of current research in human genetics, including an understanding of common experimental and statistical techniques.  I learned a lot about how to independently read and analyze scientific papers, as well as how to present and discuss research in human genetics.

I learned how to understand recent human genomics research and think about the implications of each paper for future research questions. I also learned about major techniques and their strengths and weaknesses.

I learned a lot about how to approach scientific papers and navigate technical jargon to get to the meat of the paper, with the end goal being to understand the general process and bigger applications.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Excellent course instructor and support from TA and Chris. Really enjoyed hearing the insightful observations and conversations that occurred naturally in class between all of us.
The course has a detail-oriented approach to reading papers, which was beneficial for my understanding of complicated biology publications.

Only 1 (maybe 2) papers per week, so you can really read them in-depth and come to class prepared. Also, discussions would take up the whole 2 hr class period just for 1 paper, meaning that the discussion wasn't rushed and you could really learn about papers well.

Strengths: The teaching team was great and knowledgeable! The workload was fair, and the papers were very interesting to read. Weaknesses: Maybe doing an quick overview of common statistical tools used in genetics research may be helpful. We had talked about a ton in class, but doing a quick lecture with them might help pack down the material more!

Strengths: course format is highly adaptable and allows us to discuss very current literature
Weaknesses: it would have been good to have "crash courses" on topics, techniques, or methods of statistical analysis that come up frequently in papers but might not have been taught to all students in prior classes.

This is unlike any other course at Yale you get the full seminar experience of discussing papers without the added pressure of written assignments. Highly recommend. The teaching team is also fantastic.
I think it was perfect as it was

If it can be fit into class time, an in-depth explanation of a major genomics technique at the beginning of each class might help students solidify their understanding of genomics research methodologies since we don't always get the chance to dive into discussions about the specific tools that the researchers use.

The course was very easygoing, and Professor Dellaporta created a friendly environment in which students could express confusion without feeling like they would be berated or judged by their fellow classmates. Having only one paper to read each week meant we could focus on it and dedicate the proper amount of time to understanding it, rather than aimlessly skimming. I can't think of any weaknesses except that the class itself was later in the day, so when the sun set, everyone's energy dropped (but that's not a weakness of the class itself, just its timeslot).

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, absolutely! I loved the course and feel that it was so satisfying in terms of what I learned and gained from the course.
Absolutely! A great class and is one of the few upper division seminars offered by MCDB.
Yes! Great class to keep up with current literature in genetics

Yes! It's difficult to get into because it's limited to around 15-18 students, but if you get in, definitely take it! Especially if you are any type of STEM major, it's a super helpful class to learn how to read scientific literature and learn about different genomics techniques (GWAS, sequencing, etc.)
Yes
I would highly recommend this course to any MCDB major looking for a seminar. The teaching team is awesome and the workload is very fair.
Yes, it helped me improve my scientific paper reading skills which is essential for anyone who aspires to work in a science or science-adjacent field.
Yes! If you can get into this class, I highly recommend taking it.

ABSOLUTELY! It's structured in such a way that it first and foremost ensures that the students learn the material by providing an environment where learning is the main objective and takes away the other stress that might be associated with it. It was a safe and fun space and I looked forward to going to class each Monday because of it.
Yes, if you're interested in human genetics/genomics and would like to take an in-depth look at the research currently going on in the field!

Yes, I would highly recommend this course because I learned a lot about the current state of genomics research and technologies and the questions that might be open for future researchers to tackle. Professor Dellaporta picks papers from across a range of fields in human genomics, including medical genetics, population genetics, and evolutionary genetics, so I got a sense of how the research differs between each field and which one I might be most interested in. The seminar format encouraged students to have a strong understanding of the motivations and methods behind each figure and made the class more engaging.

Yes, I would highly recommend this class to anyone that wants to learn more about genetics or generally how to read a scientific paper! I went in with little experience with scientific work, and I stated that in my application; Professor Dellaporta helped me a lot in navigating dense papers, and our teaching assistants were phenomenal.
